comment_text: When you think about how guys like us use to stress about how little real hard science was available for us back before Youtube days. Well, especially those of us that are over 35. When you think about that time compared to now, this channel only has 234K subscribers! Anyway, Tim, I have a question that has been bothering me since SpaceX erected one of is't rockets in front of their Hawthorne, California location. I live nearby and every time I drive by there, I wonder why they didn't put the second stage and payload housing on top of that rocket, so it looks like a rocket? Instead, it looks like a factory smokestack, next to a factory...
Everyday Astronaut, I realize there is a very small chance you will see this but could you do a video about the Dragon (and Dragon 2) cargo vehicles?

I think you’re too dismissive of the idea of a gravity centrifuge inside of a BFS.  It appears they’re now designing a BFS just for tourists. Previously the tourist was going to fly in a dragon capsule designed for taking crew to the ISS.  With a tourist version of BFS, after its first lunar flyby cruise, they send in the housekeeping staff and soon it is ready for its next cruise.  In that case they need to minimize training and maximize convenience. Perhaps put 12 cabins in a rotating section in the rear, each cabin having a bed, eating area and bathroom, then when zero-gravity nausea occurs just go your cabin and try to sleep it off. The dizziness-inducing effects of the centrifuge shouldn’t matter if you’re sleeping or moving slowly, and should be preferable to the nausea-inducing effects of zero gravity. It would not be good for space tourism if the first group of space artists documented how difficult it is to be a space tourist.

Someone at SpaceX should try to research a more practical solution to produce gravity on a spacecraft. There have been some works done in Europe back in 2006 using electromagnetism in an ESA lab that levitated a frog which in theory if thrown in reverse could produce 1G of gravity on a surface in a weightless environment but not much has been done since then. We won’t go far without a practical means to produce gravity in a spacecraft.

I think your logic on simulated gravity is flawed. While yes they probably CAN stay in space for a 3-6 month period that does not mean that they should have to. The first people on a new world will need their strength. And even a small loss of physical ability will be stupid to plan on if it's relativt easy to design around with two ships spinning around a point. Just the possibility of someone getting more serious problems world be a huge problem in the early days of Mars, maybe even fatal. While people return from LEO all the time from extended stays in space, those who get to Mars will be met by noone to help them unlike here where there is literally an army waiting to carry them and get them to a rehabilitation center. I think if someone after spending half a year in space was lost on entry and somehow had to fend for them selves for anything past a few days would be a real struggle for survival, if survivable at all. Honestly I think they should simulate Mars gravity on the trip to get used to it. Love your show everyday astronaut! Keep up the great work. So pumped for this upcoming event!

I like your work and your enthusiasm, but I disagree on your dismissal of the microgravity problem.

After 5 months people returning from the ISS cannot walk or stand on their own - see the pictures in this article:
https://www.mirror.co.uk/science/gallery/incredible-images-reveal-moment-three-12644030

It's not going to be that much better after 4 months and the envisioned 3 months travel time is a very optimistic best case scenario...
Don't just dismiss a potential problem just because there's no solution for it right now, that's a very naive approach. There's absolutely nothing wrong with simply saying: nobody knows if the lack of gravity is going to be a serious issue. And even if it is - it might just be a risk worth taking. Simply dismissing it outright, however, is a really dumb way of looking at it TBH.

On the BFS (or any ship) spinning.  Look up the work of Dr. Elizabeth Blaber of Nasa.  She has identified a gene called P21 that appears to be a master regulator of bone density.  This is not the "load sensor" gene in my opinion, but another gene in that pathway will be.  The implication of this is that within 5 years we may be able to biochemically/genetically explain why muscles atrophy in 0g, it might take a decade after that to find a remedy for humans.   But - we aren't that far away.
